name: Persian
description: The Persian is one of the oldest and most popular cat breeds, known for its long, luxurious coat and sweet, gentle personality.
overview: The Persian is one of the oldest and most recognizable cat breeds in the world. With their distinctive flat face, round eyes, and flowing coat, they've been prized companions for centuries. Persians are the epitome of a lap cat—calm, sweet-natured, and content to lounge in comfort.
health: Persians are prone to Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD), respiratory issues due to their flat face (brachycephalic syndrome), and eye conditions like excessive tearing. Regular vet checkups and genetic testing are recommended. Their flat face can also cause dental issues.
care: Daily grooming is essential to prevent matting of their long coat. Their eyes need regular cleaning due to tear staining. Keep them indoors as their coat and flat face make them vulnerable. Feed a high-quality diet and monitor weight as they're prone to obesity.

name: Maine Coon
description: The Maine Coon is one of the largest domestic cat breeds, known as the 'gentle giant' for its friendly, dog-like personality.
overview: The Maine Coon is America's native longhaired cat and one of the largest domesticated breeds. Known as 'gentle giants,' they combine impressive size with a friendly, dog-like personality. They're excellent mousers with a rugged appearance suited to harsh New England winters.
health: Maine Coons can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM), hip dysplasia, and Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA). Regular cardiac screening is recommended. Despite their size, they're generally healthy cats with proper care and can live 12-15 years.
care: Their semi-long coat needs brushing 2-3 times weekly to prevent matting. They enjoy interactive play and need space to climb and explore. Provide sturdy cat trees that can support their weight. They often enjoy water and may 'help' with dishes!

name: Ragdoll
description: Ragdolls are known for going limp when picked up, hence their name. They're extremely docile, loving cats that follow their owners around.
overview: Ragdolls are named for their tendency to go limp and relaxed when picked up. Developed in California in the 1960s, they're known for their striking blue eyes, semi-long coat, and incredibly docile temperament. They follow their owners from room to room like puppies.
health: Ragdolls can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) and bladder stones. They may also develop Feline Infectious Peritonitis (FIP). Regular cardiac screening is recommended. Their laid-back nature means monitoring for obesity is important.
care: Their silky coat is easier to maintain than other longhairs—brush 2-3 times weekly. They're strictly indoor cats due to their trusting nature. Provide plenty of soft beds and perches. They thrive on companionship and don't do well left alone for long periods.

name: British Shorthair
description: The British Shorthair is a pedigreed version of the British domestic cat, known for its chunky body, dense coat, and broad face.

not_ideal: Those wanting a very active cat

overview: The British Shorthair is one of the oldest English cat breeds, descending from Roman-era cats. Famous for their round face, dense 'crisp' coat, and copper eyes, they're often compared to teddy bears. They're calm, dignified cats that become deeply loyal to their families.
health: British Shorthairs can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM), Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD), and obesity. They may also develop hemophilia B. Regular health screenings and weight management are important for this stocky breed.
care: Their dense coat needs weekly brushing, more during shedding season. They're not demanding of attention but enjoy routine. Monitor food intake as they gain weight easily. Provide interactive toys as they can be less active than other breeds.

name: Siamese
description: Siamese cats are one of the most recognizable breeds with their striking blue eyes and colorpoint coat. They're extremely vocal and social.
overview: The Siamese is one of the most ancient and recognizable cat breeds, originating from Thailand (formerly Siam). With their striking blue almond eyes, pointed coloring, and vocal personality, they're impossible to ignore. Siamese form intense bonds with their chosen humans.
health: Siamese cats can be prone to respiratory issues, dental problems, and Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA). Some may develop amyloidosis or certain cancers. They're also prone to compulsive behaviors like wool-sucking. Regular vet visits are important.
care: Their short coat needs minimal grooming—weekly brushing is enough. They need lots of mental stimulation and interactive play. Consider getting two as they don't like being alone. Be prepared for their vocal nature—they will 'talk' to you constantly!

name: Abyssinian
description: Abyssinians are one of the oldest known breeds, known for their ticked coat and extremely active, curious nature.
overview: The Abyssinian is one of the oldest known cat breeds, with a distinctive 'ticked' coat that gives them a wild appearance. Often called the 'Aby,' they're incredibly active, curious, and intelligent. These cats are natural athletes who love to climb and explore everything.
health: Abyssinians can be prone to Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency (PKD), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), and renal amyloidosis. Dental issues are also common. Genetic testing is available for many conditions. With proper care, they live 12-15 years.
care: Their short, ticked coat needs minimal grooming. However, they need lots of play and mental stimulation—puzzle feeders are great. Provide tall cat trees and high perches. They don't do well left alone and may become destructive if bored.

name: Bengal
description: Bengals have a wild appearance with their leopard-like spots but are fully domesticated. They're highly active and love water.
overview: Bengals were created by crossing domestic cats with Asian Leopard Cats, giving them their stunning wild appearance. Their spotted or marbled coat resembles a miniature leopard, but they're fully domesticated. They're incredibly athletic, intelligent, and often love water.
health: Bengals can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), and Flat Chested Kitten Syndrome. Some may have sensitive stomachs. Buy from reputable breeders who test for genetic conditions.
care: Their short, luxurious coat needs minimal grooming. However, they need extensive play and exercise—at least 30 minutes of active play daily. Provide climbing structures, puzzle toys, and consider leash training. Many Bengals enjoy playing in water.

name: Sphynx
description: The Sphynx is famous for being hairless, though they have a fine peach-fuzz. They're extremely affectionate and love being warm.
overview: The Sphynx appears hairless but actually has a fine peach-fuzz covering. Developed in Canada in the 1960s, they're known for their wrinkled skin, large ears, and incredibly affectionate personality. Don't let their alien appearance fool you—they're total love bugs.
health: Sphynx cats can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM), skin conditions, and respiratory issues. They're also sensitive to temperature extremes. Regular dental care is important as they're prone to gum disease.
care: Despite being 'hairless,' they need regular bathing (weekly) as oils build up on their skin. Keep them warm—sweaters may be needed in winter. Clean their large ears regularly. They need to be indoor cats and protected from sunburn.

name: Scottish Fold
description: Scottish Folds are known for their unique folded ears and owl-like appearance. They're sweet-natured and adaptable.

not_ideal: Those concerned about genetic health issues

overview: Scottish Folds are instantly recognizable by their folded ears that give them an 'owl-like' appearance. Originating from a barn cat in Scotland in 1961, they're known for their round face and sweet expression. They often sit in unusual positions, including the 'Buddha sit.'
health: Scottish Folds can develop Osteochondrodysplasia, a cartilage/bone condition related to the folded ear gene. This can cause painful arthritis. Never breed fold-to-fold. Watch for signs of joint pain or stiffness. Regular vet monitoring is essential.
care: Their coat (short or long variety) needs weekly brushing. Handle their ears gently and check for wax buildup. Monitor for any signs of joint discomfort. They're adaptable and easygoing, making them good apartment cats.

name: Birman
description: Birmans are known as the 'Sacred Cat of Burma' with their striking blue eyes and white 'gloves' on their paws.

name: Russian Blue
description: Russian Blues are known for their plush blue-grey coat and striking green eyes. They're shy with strangers but devoted to their family.
overview: The Russian Blue is known for their stunning silver-blue coat and vivid green eyes. Believed to originate from the Russian port of Arkhangelsk, they're elegant, reserved cats that form deep bonds with their families while being shy with strangers.
health: Russian Blues are generally healthy with few breed-specific issues. They can be prone to obesity and bladder stones. Some may develop eye issues. They're one of the healthier purebred cats with lifespans often reaching 15-20 years.
care: Their dense double coat needs weekly brushing. They're creatures of habit and may be stressed by changes. Provide consistent routines and quiet spaces. They're good for people with mild allergies as they produce less Fel d 1 protein.

name: Norwegian Forest Cat
description: Norwegian Forest Cats are large, rugged cats with a thick waterproof coat developed to survive Scandinavian winters.
overview: The Norwegian Forest Cat, or 'Wegie,' is a natural breed from Scandinavia built for harsh winters. With their thick double coat, tufted ears, and bushy tail, they're perfectly adapted to cold climates. These gentle giants are independent yet affectionate with their families.
health: Norwegian Forest Cats can be prone to Glycogen Storage Disease IV (GSD IV), Hip Dysplasia, and Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). Reputable breeders test for these conditions. They're generally healthy cats with lifespans of 14-16 years.
care: Their thick double coat needs brushing 2-3 times weekly, daily during shedding season. They're natural climbers and need tall cat trees. Despite their wild appearance, they adapt well to indoor living. Keep them mentally stimulated with puzzle toys.

name: Burmese
description: Burmese cats are known for their dog-like personality, following their owners everywhere and being extremely social.
overview: The Burmese is a compact, muscular cat with a silky coat and expressive golden eyes. Originally from Burma (Myanmar), they're known for their dog-like personality and unwavering devotion to their humans. They're often called 'velcro cats' for how closely they stick to their owners.
health: Burmese can be prone to Diabetes Mellitus, Hypokalemia (low potassium), and cranial deformities in some lines. They may also develop eye conditions. Regular vet checkups are important. With good care, they live 15-18 years.
care: Their short, satin coat needs minimal grooming—weekly brushing is enough. They're highly social and don't do well alone; consider getting two. They remain playful well into adulthood and need daily interactive play. Watch their diet as they can gain weight.

name: Oriental Shorthair
description: Oriental Shorthairs come in over 300 color combinations. They're like Siamese without the colorpoint pattern - very vocal and social.
overview: The Oriental Shorthair is essentially a Siamese in a rainbow of colors and patterns—over 300 combinations! With their large ears, almond eyes, and sleek body, they're strikingly elegant. Like their Siamese cousins, they're extremely vocal and form intense bonds with their humans.
health: Orientals can be prone to Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), liver amyloidosis, and heart issues. Some may develop asthma or bronchial disease. They're also prone to dental issues. Regular vet visits and dental care are important.
care: Their short coat needs minimal grooming. However, they need lots of attention and mental stimulation—they get depressed if ignored. Provide puzzle feeders, interactive toys, and plenty of playtime. They do best with a companion cat or very attentive owner.

name: Devon Rex
description: Devon Rex cats have large ears, an elfin face, and a wavy coat. They're known as 'pixie cats' for their mischievous personality.
overview: The Devon Rex is an elfin-looking cat with huge ears, large eyes, and a curly coat. Discovered in Devon, England in 1960, they're often called 'pixie cats' or 'alien cats.' They're mischievous, playful, and love being the center of attention.
health: Devon Rex can be prone to Hereditary Myopathy (muscle weakness), Patellar Luxation, and Hip Dysplasia. Some develop skin conditions. They may also be prone to yeast infections in their ears. Regular health screenings are recommended.
care: Their wavy coat needs gentle weekly wiping rather than brushing. Clean their large ears regularly. They get cold easily and may need sweaters. They're food-obsessed and will steal from plates—monitor their diet carefully!

name: Cornish Rex
description: Cornish Rex have a distinctive wavy coat and slender body. They're athletic, love to play fetch, and stay kitten-like their whole lives.

not_ideal: Those wanting a calm lap cat

overview: The Cornish Rex has a distinctive curly coat that feels like crushed velvet. Originating from Cornwall, England, they have an elegant, arched body and egg-shaped head. They're playful, acrobatic cats that retain kitten-like energy throughout their lives.
health: Cornish Rex can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM), Patellar Luxation, and skin sensitivity. Their lack of guard hairs makes them sensitive to temperature. They may develop umbilical hernias. Generally healthy with 12-15 year lifespans.
care: Their unique coat needs minimal grooming—occasional gentle brushing. They get cold easily and appreciate warm spots and heated beds. Their large ears need regular cleaning. High metabolism means they need quality food and may eat more than expected.

name: Exotic Shorthair
description: Exotic Shorthairs are essentially short-haired Persians - same sweet face and gentle nature but with easier grooming needs.

best_for: Those who love Persians but not grooming

overview: The Exotic Shorthair is essentially a short-haired Persian—same sweet face and calm personality, but with an easier-to-maintain coat. Often called 'the lazy man's Persian,' they combine the Persian's gentle nature with lower grooming needs.
health: Exotics share Persian health issues: Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD), respiratory problems from their flat face, and eye conditions. They may also develop Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). Regular vet checkups and PKD screening are important.
care: Their dense coat needs brushing 2-3 times weekly. Their flat face requires daily eye cleaning to prevent staining. Keep them cool in summer as they can overheat. They're content with moderate play and lots of lap time.

name: Himalayan
description: Himalayans combine Persian features with Siamese colorpoints. They're sweet, calm cats that love peaceful environments.
overview: The Himalayan combines the Persian's luxurious coat with Siamese colorpoint markings. These stunning cats have the Persian's calm, sweet temperament but may show occasional Siamese playfulness. They're gentle, devoted companions who prefer serene environments.
health: Himalayans are prone to the same issues as Persians: PKD, respiratory problems, eye conditions, and dental issues from their flat face. They may also develop skin fold dermatitis. Regular grooming and vet care are essential.
care: Daily grooming is essential to prevent matting of their long coat. Clean their eyes daily. Keep them in air-conditioned spaces during hot weather. They're indoor-only cats who prefer quiet, predictable routines.

name: American Shorthair
description: American Shorthairs are the pedigreed version of domestic shorthairs - athletic, adaptable, and great family cats.
overview: The American Shorthair descended from cats brought to America on the Mayflower. They're the 'working cats' of the breed world—hardy, adaptable, and excellent mousers. With their muscular build and variety of colors, they're quintessentially American cats.
health: American Shorthairs are generally very healthy with few breed-specific issues. Some may be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). They can gain weight easily, so diet management is important. Lifespan is typically 15-20 years.
care: Weekly brushing keeps their dense coat healthy. They're low-maintenance cats who adapt to various living situations. Provide opportunities for hunting play to satisfy their natural instincts. Monitor food intake as they love to eat.

name: Tonkinese
description: Tonkinese are a cross between Siamese and Burmese, combining the best of both - social, playful, and loving.
overview: The Tonkinese is a cross between Siamese and Burmese, combining the best of both breeds. They have aqua eyes, a medium build, and a silky coat. Playful, social, and talkative (but less than Siamese), they're the perfect middle ground.
health: Tonkinese can inherit health issues from both parent breeds: respiratory infections, dental problems, and crossed eyes (rare). They may also be prone to inflammatory bowel disease. Generally healthy with 12-16 year lifespans.
care: Their silky coat needs only weekly brushing. They're highly social and need companionship—they don't do well alone. Provide lots of interactive toys and climbing opportunities. They remain playful and curious throughout life.

name: Ragamuffin
description: Ragamuffins are similar to Ragdolls but come in more colors. They're extremely gentle, patient, and love being held.
overview: The RagaMuffin is closely related to the Ragdoll but comes in more colors and patterns. These large, cuddly cats are known for their docile temperament and tendency to go limp when held. They're often described as 'puppy-like' in their devotion.
health: RagaMuffins can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) and Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD). They may also develop obesity if overfed. Genetic testing is available. With proper care, they live 12-16 years.
care: Their silky coat resists matting but benefits from weekly brushing. They're not demanding but love attention. Provide sturdy furniture—they're large cats! Keep them indoors as their trusting nature makes them vulnerable outside.

name: Savannah
description: Savannahs are a hybrid breed (African Serval x domestic cat). They're tall, athletic, and have a wild appearance.
overview: The Savannah is a hybrid between a domestic cat and an African Serval, resulting in a tall, spotted, wild-looking cat. They're highly active, intelligent, and bond strongly with their owners. Early generations (F1-F3) retain more wild characteristics.
health: Savannahs are generally healthy but may be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). Some have sensitive stomachs. Note: They may react differently to certain medications and anesthetics. Find a vet experienced with hybrid cats.
care: They need lots of space and exercise—not apartment cats! Provide tall cat trees, puzzle feeders, and interactive play. Many can be leash trained. They may learn to open doors and turn on faucets. Secure your home well!

name: Siberian
description: Siberians are Russia's native forest cat with a luxurious triple coat. They're known to produce less Fel d 1 allergen.
overview: The Siberian is Russia's native forest cat, known for their thick triple coat and powerful build. Despite their size, they're agile jumpers and playful hunters. They're also notable for producing less Fel d 1 allergen, making them better for some allergy sufferers.
health: Siberians can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) and PKD. Some lines have hereditary cancer. They're generally robust cats, well-adapted to harsh conditions. Regular cardiac screening is recommended. Lifespan is 12-15 years.
care: Their thick coat needs brushing 2-3 times weekly, daily during shedding season. They love water and may join you in the shower! Provide opportunities for climbing and hunting play. They're adaptable to various living situations.

name: Balinese
description: Balinese are essentially long-haired Siamese - same personality and colorpoints with a silky flowing coat.
overview: The Balinese is essentially a long-haired Siamese, with the same striking blue eyes and colorpoint pattern but with a silky, flowing coat. Named for their graceful movements reminiscent of Balinese dancers, they're intelligent, vocal, and deeply affectionate.
health: Balinese share health concerns with Siamese: Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), liver amyloidosis, and respiratory issues. They may also be prone to dental problems. Regular vet checkups and dental care are important.
care: Their single-layer coat doesn't mat easily—weekly brushing is enough. They need lots of mental stimulation and interaction. Provide puzzle toys and climbing spaces. They don't like being alone and may become destructive if bored.

name: Turkish Angora
description: Turkish Angoras are one of the ancient natural breeds, known for their elegant silky coat and graceful movements.
overview: The Turkish Angora is an ancient, natural breed from Turkey, known for their silky white coat and graceful appearance. Contrary to their delicate looks, they're energetic, mischievous, and highly intelligent. They often bond most closely with one person.
health: White Turkish Angoras with blue eyes may be deaf. They can be prone to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) and Hereditary Ataxia. Some may develop sensitivity to anesthetics. Get hearing tested if buying a white kitten.
care: Their single-layer coat doesn't mat easily—weekly brushing is sufficient. They're active cats who need lots of play and climbing opportunities. They can be trained to fetch and walk on a leash. Supervise around water—they're fascinated by it!

name: Turkish Van
description: Turkish Vans are known as 'swimming cats' for their love of water. They have a distinctive color pattern - white body with colored head/tail.
overview: The Turkish Van is famous for loving water—they're often called 'the swimming cats.' Originating from Turkey's Lake Van region, they have a distinctive pattern with color only on their head and tail. They're energetic, athletic, and love to climb.
health: Turkish Vans are generally healthy with few breed-specific issues. Some may be prone to heart conditions. All-white Vans with blue eyes may be deaf. They're a robust, natural breed with lifespans of 12-17 years.
care: Their semi-long, water-resistant coat needs minimal grooming—it lacks an undercoat. Provide lots of climbing space and, if possible, access to water for play. They're highly active and need space to run. Not ideal for small apartments.

name: Somali
description: Somalis are long-haired Abyssinians with the same active, curious personality and beautiful ticked coat.
overview: The Somali is a long-haired Abyssinian, with the same ticked coat and fox-like appearance but with a flowing mane and bushy tail. They're incredibly active, curious, and playful—often called 'fox cats' for their appearance and clever personality.
health: Somalis share Abyssinian health concerns: Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), and renal amyloidosis. Dental issues are also common. Genetic testing is available for many conditions. Lifespan is 12-16 years.
care: Their medium-length coat needs brushing 2-3 times weekly to prevent matting. They need lots of play, climbing space, and mental stimulation. Puzzle feeders are great. They don't do well alone—consider getting two.

name: Chartreux
description: Chartreux are France's native blue cat, known for their quiet nature and sweet 'smiling' expression.
overview: The Chartreux is France's native cat, known for their blue-gray 'waterproof' coat and copper eyes. Often called 'smiling cats' for their expression, they're quiet, gentle, and observant. They're excellent hunters who bond deeply with their families.
health: Chartreux can be prone to Patellar Luxation (knee issues) and Polycystic Kidney Disease. Some may develop urinary tract issues. They're generally healthy, robust cats with lifespans of 12-15 years.
care: Their dense, woolly coat needs weekly brushing, more during shedding. They're adaptable cats who handle travel well. Provide hunting toys to satisfy their natural instincts. They're not demanding but enjoy interactive play.

name: Ocicat
description: Ocicats look wild but are completely domestic. They're dog-like in their devotion and can learn tricks.
overview: The Ocicat looks wild with their spotted coat but is entirely domestic—a mix of Siamese, Abyssinian, and American Shorthair. They're confident, outgoing, and dog-like in their devotion. Many can be trained to fetch, walk on a leash, and respond to commands.
health: Ocicats can be prone to liver or renal amyloidosis (inherited from Siamese/Abyssinian). Some may develop Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) or Progressive Retinal Atrophy. Generally healthy with 12-18 year lifespans.
care: Their short, spotted coat needs only weekly brushing. They're highly social and need companionship—they do well with other pets. Provide lots of interactive play and puzzle toys. They can be trained like dogs with positive reinforcement.

name: Egyptian Mau
description: Egyptian Maus are the fastest domestic cat breed and the only naturally spotted domestic cat. They're loyal but shy with strangers.
overview: The Egyptian Mau is the only naturally spotted domestic cat, with ancestry possibly tracing to ancient Egypt. They're the fastest domestic cat breed, capable of running 30 mph! Reserved with strangers but devoted to their families, they're sensitive, loyal cats.
health: Egyptian Maus can be prone to Leukodystrophy (a neurological condition) and heart disease. Some may develop urolithiasis (bladder stones). They're sensitive to cold and anesthesia. Regular vet checkups are important.
care: Their short, spotted coat needs minimal grooming. They're sensitive cats who prefer calm environments and consistent routines. Provide lots of running space and climbing opportunities. They bond deeply and don't like being left alone.

name: Singapura
description: Singapuras are the smallest cat breed but have huge personalities. They love being involved in everything.

name: Manx
description: Manx cats are known for their lack of tail (or short tail). They're playful, dog-like, and excellent hunters.

name: Japanese Bobtail
description: Japanese Bobtails have a distinctive pom-pom tail. They're the 'lucky cat' breed featured in the maneki-neko figurine.

name: American Curl
description: American Curls have unique backward-curling ears. They stay kitten-like throughout their lives and are very people-oriented.

name: Selkirk Rex
description: Selkirk Rex have a curly 'sheep-like' coat. They're the most relaxed of the Rex breeds with a patient, tolerant nature.

name: LaPerm
description: LaPerms have a unique curly coat that can range from wavy to ringlet curls. They're affectionate and love being close to people.

not_ideal: Those wanting a very active cat

name: Korat
description: Korats are one of the oldest stable cat breeds, considered good luck in Thailand. They form strong bonds with their chosen person.

name: Bombay
description: Bombays were bred to look like mini black panthers. They're incredibly affectionate and love being the center of attention.

name: Havana Brown
description: Havana Browns are rare cats with a distinctive mahogany brown coat and green eyes. They're charming and love human interaction.

name: Burmilla
description: Burmillas are a cross between Burmese and Chinchilla Persian, combining the best of both - sweet nature and beautiful silver coat.

name: Toyger
description: Toygers are bred to look like toy tigers with their bold striped pattern. Despite wild looks, they're friendly and laid-back.

name: Pixie-Bob
description: Pixie-Bobs look like bobcats but are fully domestic. They're known for their dog-like loyalty and can learn to walk on a leash.

name: Cymric
description: Cymrics are long-haired Manx cats, sharing the same tailless gene. They're gentle, playful, and bond strongly with their families.

name: American Bobtail
description: American Bobtails have a naturally short tail and wild appearance. They're known as 'golden retrievers of the cat world' for their friendly nature.

name: Nebelung
description: Nebelungs are the long-haired version of Russian Blues with the same shy, gentle nature and stunning blue coat.

name: Snowshoe
description: Snowshoes have Siamese coloring with white 'snowshoe' feet. They're social butterflies who hate being alone.

name: Chausie
description: Chausies are a hybrid breed (Jungle Cat x domestic). They're tall, athletic, and need lots of space and activity.

name: Sokoke
description: Sokokes are a natural breed from Kenya with a distinctive modified tabby pattern. They're athletic and bond strongly with families.

name: Australian Mist
description: Australian Mists are Australia's first pedigreed breed, developed to be the perfect indoor companion - tolerant, gentle, and low-maintenance.

name: Peterbald
description: Peterbalds can range from bald to brush-coated. They're elegant, dog-like in devotion, and love being warm.

name: Donskoy
description: Donskoys are Russian hairless cats with a different gene than the Sphynx. They're extremely social and can even have 'winter coats'.

name: Kurilian Bobtail
description: Kurilian Bobtails come from the Kuril Islands. They're excellent fishers with a pom-pom tail and gentle, trusting nature.

name: American Wirehair
description: American Wirehairs have a unique springy, crimped coat. They're adaptable, quiet, and make excellent companions.

name: European Shorthair
description: European Shorthairs are the pedigreed version of European domestic cats - hardy, healthy, and versatile.

name: Brazilian Shorthair
description: Brazilian Shorthairs are Brazil's first pedigreed breed, developed from street cats of Brazil. They're friendly and adaptable.

name: Khao Manee
description: Khao Manees are ancient Thai cats, known as 'White Gem'. Many have odd-colored eyes (one blue, one gold).

name: Lykoi
description: Lykoi, or 'Werewolf Cat', has a unique partially hairless coat. Despite spooky looks, they're friendly and dog-like.

name: Munchkin
description: Munchkins have naturally short legs but are just as active as other cats. They're playful and love to collect shiny things.

name: Highlander
description: Highlanders have curled ears and often a bobbed tail. They're confident, clownish, and love being the center of attention.

name: Serengeti
description: Serengetis were bred to look like wild Servals but are fully domestic. They're tall, spotted, and very active.

name: Thai
description: Thai cats are the traditional, old-style Siamese with a less extreme body type. They're social, vocal, and loving.

name: Chantilly-Tiffany
description: Chantilly-Tiffanies have a gorgeous silky coat and devoted personality. They're moderate in energy and very loyal.

name: York Chocolate
description: York Chocolates are a rare American breed with rich chocolate or lavender colored coats. They're friendly farm-cat types.

name: Colorpoint Shorthair
description: Colorpoint Shorthairs are essentially Siamese in non-traditional colors (red, cream, tortie, lynx points).

name: Javanese
description: Javanese are long-haired Colorpoint Shorthairs - same Siamese personality with a silky coat in various point colors.

name: Oriental Longhair
description: Oriental Longhairs are the long-haired version of Oriental Shorthairs - elegant, vocal, and extremely social.

name: British Longhair
description: British Longhairs are the long-haired version of British Shorthairs - same calm nature with a luxurious fluffy coat.

name: Asian
description: Asian cats are Burmese-type cats in non-traditional colors and patterns. They share the loving Burmese personality.

name: Tiffanie
description: Tiffanies are the semi-longhaired version of the Burmilla, combining the beautiful silver coat with a gentle nature.

name: California Spangled
description: California Spangled cats were bred to resemble wild leopards. They're athletic, curious, and love to hunt and play.

name: Dragon Li
description: Dragon Li (Chinese Li Hua) is China's only recognized native breed. They're intelligent, independent, and make good hunters.

name: Suphalak
description: Suphalaks are ancient Thai cats, mentioned in the Cat Book Poems. They have a unique copper/brown coat and loving nature.

name: Aphrodite Giant
description: Aphrodite Giants are a natural breed from Cyprus, known for their large size and gentle nature. They're one of the oldest breeds.

name: Cyprus
description: Cyprus cats are the domestic cats native to the island of Cyprus, with a history going back thousands of years.
